articles.title: INTERVIEW: Air Peace will continue to provide jobs, peace to Nigerians, billionaire founder, Allen Onyema
articles.text:
By AZUH AMATUS

With several solid and well maintained aircraft, one of the newest entrants into Nigeria’s tough and highly competitive aviation industry, Air Peace, has left no one in doubt that it has come to stay and make a huge difference in the sector.

Barrister Allen Ifechukwu Onyema, the amiable and cerebral billionaire Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the wave making airline that began operations with a bang in October 2014, in this exclusive interview with the Publisher and Editor-in-Chief of DAYLIGHT, Azuh Amatus, took us down memory lane on a wide gamut of issues.

The peace-loving University of Ibadan trained lawyer and founder of the Foundation for Ethnic Harmony in Nigeria (FEHN), in this encounter that held inside his upscale GRA Ikeja, Lagos office, also spoke extensively and passionately about the pains and gains of owing an airline company in Nigeria.

The philanthropist extraordinaire also bared his mind on why government should abolish multiple taxes in the sector, reasons recapitalisation is not good for the industry, how Air Peace was divinely set up to fulfil a national promise, the importance of safety, challenges and many more. Enjoy the doting father of four in this rare encounter.

Your historic Air Peace is very new and making huge impact in the nation’s highly competitive and tough aviation sector, as the Chairman/CEO, how does that make you feel?

Well, I feel just like any other person who has experienced what you just said. I’m very happy and we give honour and glory to God almighty for the journey so far. We are very happy, it has not been rosy, a lot of hurdles and challenges but we have been able to surmount a great lot of these challenges and hurdles. We are coasting very smoothly and I thank God almighty for not letting His airline go down.

As a strong stakeholder, do you think government is doing enough to sincerely encourage private sector participation in the nation’s aviation industry?

Well, I might not give you a direct answer, but will give you scenarios. This government has done a lot in improving airports infrastructure nationwide that is one. This same government has also removed import duties on commercial aircrafts acquisitions and this has gone a long way in putting some money back into the pockets of airline owners so they could use that for other things rather than only the acquisition of these aircrafts. Before, after buying your aircrafts you have to pay heavily to get the aircrafts in through import duties. Now government has removed those duties or taxes and it has helped greatly. But there are still a lot of rooms for improvement. One is the multiplicity of taxes from government agencies. We have NCAA, FAAN, NEMA, NAMA, NIMET and all sorts of agencies asking you to pay between 5% and 10% taxes or duties. The multiplicity of taxes has not really helped the airlines in Nigeria. Mind you, the purchasing power of the average Nigerian is very weak, low and that means we cannot charge as much as we would have loved to charge them. So, even the little you charge, the taxes take a lot from your pockets. Government should come in and help us address this issue of multiplicity of taxes in the aviation industry.

Again, government should also address the issue of foreign exchange. Everything an airline does is computed in dollars. Two, three months ago we were buying dollars at N163/164, now you are buying dollars at N210. So, where you have expatriate pilots or staff, it is like their salaries are doubled. Again, you have to buy spare parts and we do not manufacture them in Nigeria, you have to go out there to buy these spare parts. Now, you need double the money you had before to get these spare parts. Since the dollar issue is so spontaneous, government should come in and see how they can help airline operators cushion the effect of this dollar challenge. Also, a lot of people have been talking about the recapitalisation of airlines. I think some advisers speaking on this subject do not know what it takes to recapitalise airlines. Airlines are not banks and whenever I hear people talking about recapitalisation of airlines in the same mode with banks, I laugh and this is the bane of the development of the aviation sector in Nigeria, where certain people arrogate to themselves the expertise they don’t have and try to advise government in accordance with what they think they know. Some of these advice are borne out of envy and they make it look real. Some are borne out of personal and self centred anger with the aim of scuttling certain person’s achievements. I read in the papers the other day where somebody was saying that to maintain or take an aircraft for C-Check, you need the sum of N500m that is a big lie. I own planes too and I have done C-Checks, it is not up to that. Imagine some people coming out to say that airlines should recapitalise with N5 billion each. Are you going to get the airlines to keep the sum of N5 billion aside? Is that the recapitalisation you are talking about? Airline business is not banking for goodness sake. That is why I said that some people have arrogated to themselves, the expertise they don’t have. Where in the world has such a thing happened, they should come out and tell us. Even Delta airlines, as big as they are with over 800 aircrafts, might not even have such an amount to keep somewhere. I was thinking they will be talking about the acquisition of aircrafts. For example, if you have two aircrafts and one goes bad, you are left with only one and you might get to Abuja that remaining one is snagged. Once that happens your passengers will be disappointed and stranded. Meaning your passengers will be left in the lurch because you have only two aircrafts. But if you have two aircrafts, you have to make sure that one is on standby, so you have to do your operations with one aircraft. You don’t have to schedule your two planes the same time. I might decide to have an airline that plies one destination, you can’t stop me. I don’t need to have N10 billion in one account stashed somewhere all in the name of recapitalisation. I do not want to cover the whole country, I just want to go to Abuja and come back. So, what they should be thinking is, look at the airlines, if you think there capacity can’t cover multiple routes, you make it known that if you have just two aircraft, you should not embark on multiple routes or destinations, so that you will be able to leave one aircraft on ground as a standby for emergency. It is not about keeping N5 billion somewhere. It is only in Nigeria that people talk about this kind of balderdash and painfully, people believe them. Abroad, some of these airlines don’t have a penny in their accounts. They live by financing. I also don’t believe in mergers in this country, I believe in codes sharing. Codes sharing is a situation whereby Medview and Air Peace can come together to code share. It means that may be, we are going to the same route, one day my plane may be snagged and what do I do? I will move my passengers to Medview. Codes sharing is a win-win situation, because the passengers you are moving to Medview, you are also getting a percentage of what they are paying and Medview that has accepted to fly them for you is also getting something. Some other day, it might be the turn of Medview to come to Air Peace, for the same codes sharing. And by so doing, both airlines do not lose anything. We have a lot of arm chair critics and advisers in this country, who know next to nothing and keep advising the government wrongly. I heard one of them saying the other day that Nigerian government should not allow airline operators to bring in planes more than ten years old. Even the 22 years that we are doing, the outside world is laughing at us. It is not about the age, but the maintenance. Obama’s plane, Air Force One was built in the 70s. People don’t always get it right in Nigeria. What government should be doing is to enforce adequate maintenance. Make sure that anybody floating an airline, will first tell the government how they intend maintaining the airline. That is the most important thing that is very critical. Safety is the most important thing in this business and maintenance is very, very important. But these people keep advising government wrongly that people should recapitalise with N5 billion. It is only a fool that will keep such a huge amount of money aside. Such amount of money should be put into the economy to generate jobs. Why tell me to recapitalise when I have equipment worth over N20 billion? What government should do to make sure that the airlines are strong in Nigeria is to provide the enabling environment, remove multiple taxes and look into the issue of aviation fuel. Aviation fuel is very, very high. Almost 50% percent of your cost goes into aviation fuel. They fix their prices and there is nothing you can do about it. When a plane takes off from Lagos to Abuja or any part of the country, it burns a lot of aviation fuel and most people do not know about this. In fact, Nigerians should be grateful to airline owners. Most business men don’t like going into airline operations because it is marred with low or no profits in most cases. It is not a lucrative business; therefore, most people with money don’t go into it. So, when you see people who have decided to create jobs for other people to live, what Nigerians should do is to applaud and help those people stay afloat and not bad mouth, demean and constantly disparaging them without looking at the conditions under which they operate. For somebody to bring out his hard earned money to invest in a business that is not lucrative like airline people should support them. In other countries, they doff their hats for these fearless investors because they are doing humanitarian works for the society. If they are not around, you can’t move from place to place. So instead of disparaging them, help and assist them to serve you better. Government should also come to their aid by making finances available to them. Government can also help by allowing them access a special fund where the interest rate will be a single digit. I learnt government did that some time ago and gave some people intervention fund. I’m aware that so many people that got the fund never applied for it. Sincerely, if such fund is made available again by government I would apply. I will apply because I want to be stronger than I am now. Airlines should be encouraged by all stakeholders and not only government.

Despite the low or sometimes non profit margin in the airline business, you still went ahead to invest your hard-earned billions, what is propelling this passion of yours?

I have said this number of times, in fact, thousand times on why I went into aviation business. I went into aviation to create jobs for the teeming unemployed masses of this country. Someone told me that one commercial plane can give jobs to over 120 people directly or indirectly, so i decided to go into it to create jobs.

Since coming on board fully in October last year, what would you say are the biggest challenges and obstacles facing Air Peace in its daily operations?

Well, I have found myself in an industry that is not like the background where I operate from. I came from the peace building world. I made my money from businesses, part of which is peace building and consultancy. I’m in a different world; they are two different worlds entirely. The people you meet in aviation and those you meet in the peace building community, they are miles apart, in fact, millions of miles apart. In peace building, you have a lot of people with integrity, compassion, passionate and love their colleagues by giving unconditional love at all times and ready to make sacrifices for the good of others. That is not in aviation. In aviation, it is self first, self second, self third and self till one million before considering others. This is something I found in the aviation sector that is shocking to me. Loyalty in the aviation industry is zero and compassion is lacking. It is just about self and self alone. It looks very bizarre when compared with where I was coming from. So, that is my number one disappointment. If I knew the industry is populated by that kind of people, I may not have gone into aviation. May be, I would have looked at other places to go.

Does that mean you will be shutting down Air Peace soon?

No. I will not close down Air Peace. I will make people in Air Peace think like me. I will make them buy my vision. In Air Peace, we are trying to do things differently and we are succeeding. I have fantastic staff who are trying to adjust or who have adjusted to my ways of doing things and the way we think. I come from the non violence world and we believe we can transform anybody. The first challenge is the human resources available in the industry. The second is the issue of availability of aviation fuel. One thing is to have the fuel, another is to have the money to buy it. It could be scarce sometimes and that could cause delays in operations. They could also be compromised to sabotage you. I have been sabotaged before over aviation fuel. It was prominent and happened on December 20, last year. It was designed to put Air Peace in bad light. If they had succeeded on December 20, by now Air Peace might have closed down. On that day, we were not given fuel by any marketer and our planes were not flying and our terminal was filled up with people and children were crying until we discovered that one airline had compromised and conspired with the marketers not to sell fuel to us. I ran from my house to the airport and addressed our passengers, gave them food and started pressing my buttons too. And that was when I discovered that the owners of these fuel companies did not know what was happening. Our staff thought there was scarcity, but that was not the case. It was later somebody came to tell us that one airline had compromised this people. We eventually got fuel around 6pm and started flying our passengers at night and were able to move all our passengers that day. If we had carried it over the next morning, there would have been crisis. Mind you, it was a peak period. It was designed to rubbish us, but they did not succeed. Maybe, for us to avert this happening again, government should think of allowing airlines that can afford to bring in their own fuel. If government allows that, I want to assure you that Air Peace can start providing its own fuel with support from the banks. Government should look into this area for us. I’m not interested in the business of aviation fuel marketing, but if I’m going to suffer or get blackmailed with my money, then government should start thinking of allowing any airline that can afford to get its own fuel to do so as to stabilise their operations. These are some of the challenges confronting us in this sector. New airlines like us should be allowed tax holiday for the next three years. Painfully, it is not like that in Nigeria. The other day some people came here and said they were from the tax office and that was irritating to me. It shouldn’t happen. If you do that to me, I will close down this place and throw out over 400 workers here back into the unemployment market. Those 400 people represent over 12,000 Nigerians. If every Nigerian employs 12,000 workers, there won’t be insecurity. So, instead of encouraging people like us, you will see people running around and trying to demean you, bring you down and sometimes praying for your down fall. It is a very wicked country. People do things without thinking of others. If you bring down Allen Onyema, to God be the glory, I cannot starve again in my life, but there are several people that depend on my companies for their daily bread and survival and we must begin to think of those people.

I read somewhere that your dream of establishing an airline began in 1998, but some partners later disappointed you. What spurred you on after those partners withdrew?

I was much younger then and did not know anything about aviation. In fact, I knew next o nothing about aviation in 1998 when these partners came to me with the idea. We were to go into cargo air operations with just one plane, but it did not materialise. But around 2007, somebody told me that one commercial airline can give jobs to about 120 persons directly or indirectly, so I decided I will go into it to create jobs, not to make money. But God almighty will not allow my investments to go down. I’m not in aviation to be richer or amass wealth. If I want to amass wealth, I will leave my equity in the banks. And they will give me good interest rates. That is a good business, no losses. I have been making money since 2005 and leaving money in fixed deposits. But I sincerely believe I could contribute to the well being and development of my nation whether anybody believes it or not. For those who know me, I have done great things for this country and that is one of the prime motives behind floating this airline-to create jobs. Here, our employment policy does not know tribe, religion, race or colour. The place is open; in fact, a Yoruba person is my chief operating officer, Mrs. Oluwatoyin Olajide. I have people from all parts of the country working in Air Peace. Most of these people will tell you that they didn’t know me before coming here. The door is very open for anybody, just come here and prove what you can do and you get. I don’t believe in nepotic tendencies. I want to create jobs for the people in order to fulfil the promise I made to God years ago.

You once stated publicly that the coming of Air Peace will further promote national peace and cohesion, how is that possible, taking into cognisance the crisis facing our country?

Like I told you my back ground is peace building and I’m the national chairman of the Foundation for Ethnic Harmony in Nigeria (FEHN). I have done a lot for this country. I deserve the highest honour available in this country, just that I’m really unsung because I don’t like blowing my own trumpet. I’m a good example of what you can do for your country and not what your country can do for you. When I moved round this country between 2014 and 2015 preaching ethnic harmony and doing my Nigeria forever project nobody bankrolled me. I funded myself and thousands of followers. We preached broad nationalism as against ethnic nationalism, which we have in Nigeria today. I brought non violence education into this country for the first time, with which I used to transform the Niger Delta ex militants. I started transforming them before the oil companies noticed, took me in and bankrolled me heavily to be doing it for them before the government of late Yaradua and Jonathan now noticed my contributions and supported me also. It was part of what culminated into the amnesty programme; in fact, it was the genesis of that programme. So, I have paid my dues, I could have lost my life in that process while trying to do what the military could not do. I have paid my dues and deserves the highest honour in this country. I did something nobody believed could work. Part of my using Air Peace to bridge the gap and bring about peace and national cohesion can be found in my employment policy. I also own and run ICNPD, International Centre for Nonviolence and Peace Development together with FEHN. We employ people in these places too, but with the airline, I have gone national. I see all my workers as family. Again, I just bought some special jets for Air Peace and want to use them to go to those places most Nigerians find very difficult visiting. We have deployed these jets to Kebbi State. We want to use these jets to further open up those areas planes could not land in the past. We want to see a situation where somebody from Kano can fly to Enugu directly without stopping in Abuja. What we are trying to do is interconnectivity to cities in Nigeria. When somebody from Asaba goes to Sokoto directly his mindset about people there will change directly, but when you stop over in Abuja it becomes different. All these will engender national cohesion. And you could see what we are doing with Kebbi State. Kebbi opened its airport on November 25, last year and as we speak, Air Peace is the only airline flying Kebbi, from Abuja to Kebbi, Kebbi to Abuja. We started with the 36 seater-jets, but have deployed the Boeing now because the jets could no longer carry all our passengers once. This is another of my contributions to Nigeria and I’m doing that at a very huge loss. The government of Kebbi can testify to this. Air Peace is plying Kebbi route at a huge loss, but we are happy for being given the opportunity and we are grateful to the governor, Alhaji Dakingari. A very nice man, he built one of the best airports in the whole of West Africa for the people of Kebbi State. That airport is far better than some international airports on the continent of Africa, you need to go there and see it. Now Nigerians can fly to Kebbi using Air Peace. That is part of my contribution to national unity and cohesion. The governor begged us to do this and told us they don’t have enough money to support us. I agreed because he is a very focused and hard working governor. Despite the huge loss on that route, we are happy and satisfied with the contract because we are contributing to national unity and development.

In an era where most airline companies are struggling with one or two planes, you started Air Peace with seven solid aircraft in your fleet, how did you achieve such a rare feat?

Well, if you know my history, whenever I want to do anything, I usually plan. I don’t rush into anything. The plan started since 2007. My banks are there to testify. Since 2007, I have been planning, keeping my money and planning for this day. The Americans also helped me. Just like Dr. Bernard Lafayette, who would have been charging me millions to do the non violence programmes with me. The first time he came he said I want to see this Nigerian guy who is very persistent about his nation. Even when they refused me visa to visit US with my staff for trainings, I told them to bring their faculty here for the training. He said he would like to see this persistent Nigerian. He eventually came down. He is the number one non violence trainer in the world and he worked with Dr. Martin Luther King. When he came first, I didn’t pay a penny, they gave me massive support. And when I started paying, I did not pay what others were paying. I also bought five of my planes from one company in the US. I told the man I wanted to help my country with my airline and he said Allen you have won my heart with that statement. He made it clear that it was the first time somebody from Nigeria will be coming to him and putting his country first. He’s name is Douglas Japhet, he is alive. He gave me my five planes at a price nobody in the whole world will give anybody. And that is how God works for me and people get astounded. Then the banks also helped, about two banks helped us with facilities. We are solid.

Why are most of your aircraft named after your family members, we have Chinonso, Ojochide, Nnenna, Ugochukwu, Helen among others. Why this style and concept?

Well, I believe in family, so much in family, everything starts from the family. If you are going to be a good or bad child, it starts from the family. If we get family virtues right, we may not have armed robbers. We may not have suicide bombers. Growing up, I used to be scared of doing certain things that will embarrass my family or get my parents disappointed. We were brought up that way and I’m proud of my family and have to make them part and parcel of what we are doing. That is why all the planes are bearing names of my late mum, dad, wife and four kids. I’m the only one that does not have any plane bearing my name. I have to start with others. I like satisfying others first before myself. Maybe, God willing, someday when we get more planes, one would bear my names, Ifechukwu or Allen.

How soon do you intend adding more planes to the already existing ones?

First of all, we have to solidify with what we have before we think of adding more fleet. Definitely, everybody wants to grow. We can’t continue running with a fleet of seven aircraft. We believe God almighty will do it someday. When the time comes, we will do it, we are not greedy. I hate debts, I don’t want to go out there and borrow more than I need. If I’m doing between five and seven routes like we are doing now which includes- Port Harcourt, Abuja, Asaba, Enugu, Owerri, Lagos and Birnin Kebbi, let us stabilise our operations first, then some other things will come up. Definitely, Air Peace someday will go international.

How soon do you intend activating your regional and international routes?

I think I have answered that question, one day when God blesses us, we will do it. When it is God’s time for us to do that it would be done. He is a God of miracles, anything can happen. If God says Air Peace, start going regional next month, we will do it. It is up to God and we look up to Him in everything we do. I’m a fervent believer in God and I have no apologies to anyone for that.

As a top player in the aviation sector, do you sometimes get scared of competition and competitors?

I don’t get scared by anybody. Some airlines in this country have more than 20 planes; some have between ten and eight. Air Peace has seven and I’m not scared of anybody. I don’t get scared going into things I’m convinced God allows me to do. As long as I can go on my two knees to pray I don’t get scared of anybody. I don’t fear any competition. Competitions for me should be made healthy. If a competition is healthy it will help everybody. The Nigerian flying public deserves more. They should have the best. You will agree with me that the coming of Air Peace has changed a lot in this country in the last three months or 100 days. People from the south east never had it so good before now during Xmas. But this Xmas, all of them were singing alleluia that we came on board. Nobody charged them N45,000, for economy. They didn’t have to pay through the back door to get tickets to fly or climbing over themselves to fly. They didn’t have to fall victims of fraudsters. This time around, Air Peace provided a worthy alternative to them. A lot of people were happy, enjoyed and liked it. So that is competition, it is good. Competition can even grow the market for all of us. Operators do not need to engage in devilish competitions. What we have in the industry now is what I call devilish competition. They de-market one another, wish themselves the worst, it is not good for the industry. Only competition will grow the market, less than one percent of Nigerians are flying in a country of over 170million people. So when they tell you that six million people flew this year, it’s a lie. But the fact is that some of us fly 20 times in a week and you are 20 persons in their estimation. Patronage of airlines in this country is nothing to write home about because a lot of people are scared of flying. In Nigeria, they wait for one airline to have one untoward incident; the other airlines will cash in on it and use it to finish others. They start shouting, we are the only safe one, we are the only this, we are the only that. When you are doing this, you are creating fears in the system, because a lot of people will not even fly yours. A lot of people will be discouraged from flying. When you tell certain stories and know you are lying, it will come back to you. What they should do now is to come together and develop the industry. If we have about five percent of Nigerians flying, every airline will be profitable in Nigeria. We are not scared of competition and ready to compete with anybody. Even if we have only seven planes, we re ready to compete with anybody, because we mind our own business. If you know where you are getting it, just face that place. I don’t have the capacity to cover every airport in this country. I will be stupid to try and do that now with just seven planes. Face that area you can cover and do it properly and you will be okay doing that.

We would like to know what separates Air Peace from the other airlines operating in Nigeria, those rare or special qualities that stand you out or gives you an edge?

I might be sounding very naive, but that is the truth and it is a fact. For those who don’t believe, Allen Onyema, his family and Air Peace will believe. It is simply God almighty. Sometimes, even me, I used to think that Air Peace has been there for over ten years. We keep forgetting that it is barely ten/twelve weeks. The first flight took off on October 24, 2014. In fact, by last December, we were already thinking we have been there for decades; meanwhile, we were just some weeks old. One of the things that mark us out is our safety requirement. A lot of people think that safety starts and ends with bringing beautiful airplanes or even having a maintenance company like we have. Let me tell you what Air Peace has done. First of all, you must have the right equipment and we have very good planes coming from Germany, London and United States, all coming from known airlines. My jets and planes were all working before we purchased them. I have very good planes. We have four Boeings and three Dornier jets. We have a fleet that has history. Our planes were not picked from the deserts or junkyards. Secondly, the issue of maintenance, we don’t have the manpower yet in Nigeria, local manpower. But then, the world is a global village, Nigerian engineers should aspire to be required and sought after outside Nigeria. We have Philippines all over the world working outside their country; even Ethiopian engineers are working outside their country. Nigerian engineers should do same by being competitive. In as much as Air Peace wants to develop local contents, we must also be mindful of our safety parameters. In Air Peace, it is zero tolerance for unsafe practices. Instead of employing engineers that I as the chairman will be controlling, we decided to go for a maintenance organization. We brought in BCT Aviation Maintenance Company from UK. It is a renowned maintenance company in Britain and they maintain so many airlines in the world because of their track record. Prior to engaging them, I went round the world in search of a very credible and competent maintenance organization. We ended up with BCT at a very huge cost to us. We went for them because we want our safety parameters to be impeccable. We want the safety of the lives and property of our customers to be protected at all times. We cannot buy the lives of our customers. Our safety measures stand us out. From day one when I was seeking my AOC, I made it known to the operators that they should not even cover me the moment they discover we are doing anything wrong. I don’t want anybody to help me cut corners so that we don’t derail, which was why we brought BCT. Another important issue is the flying crew. Who are the people flying your planes? Most of the accidents in aviation are caused by human errors, mostly from the pilots and engineers too. In Air Peace, we employed the best hands available anywhere to command our flight operations. I contacted my banks and told them to be ready to help our operations. Maybe, because of my integrity, Fidelity bank has been very, very supportive. They gave us some loans for operations and I have been with them for several years, maybe, they are repaying back my loyalty. Fidelity I must say again is supporting Air Peace very well. Fidelity support has helped our smooth operations. We don’t cut corners and we have integrity. I’m Air Peace, Air Peace is me. Most banks don’t give loans to airlines, but Fidelity did that for me. A lot of people will tell me that whenever Air Peace lands, it is like dropping a paper on the ground. Except where the weather is extremely bad or where a first officer undergoing training is the one landing, that is the only time. Air Peace boasts of the best pilots in this country and they are all flying our planes. I want anybody or any airline to challenge me on that. It is just only one pilot in one of the airlines that is remaining. We don’t poach pilots, they always come to us willingly because they heard that I think about other people first before myself and they have all seen it. I must thank Captain Victor Egeonu, most of his colleagues respect him and he is a pilot that has penchant for details. He is my chief pilot now and ensures that any pilot coming here is among the best in the country. All the chief pilots in other airlines in this country are currently with Air Peace. And what are we bringing to the table, experience. These are people who have been flying for over two decades without any problem. In Air Peace, we don’t make people with 3000 hours captains, our captains have amassed over 15000 hours of flights command. The experience that abounds in Air Peace is massive. We are new but populated with experienced, tested and trusted hands. Our pilots have paid their dues creditably in the aviation industry, not just anybody.

Again, our pilots are highly motivated, they are paid well and promptly too, same with our other staff. No salary delays, they receive their salaries every 25th.

My prayer to God almighty is that it continues like that.

Even if I don’t have anything for myself but still able to cover my costs at the end of the day, then glory to God. Anybody in this industry can tell you that Air Peace is where you can go and have peace. Even inside our planes, passengers always experience peace of mind. Air Peace is constantly in God’s hands and nothing will happen to it. I heard that one big airline

owner said we will fizzle out in the next three months, but that can only happen if God is no longer on the throne. God loves Air Peace and it will continue to do well.

In your sincere assessment, do you think the NCAA is truly living up to its role as the apex regulatory agency of the aviation industry?

Yes of course, the Nigerian Civil Aviation Authority is doing marvellously well. Our NCAA is one of the best in the world. Without them Nigeria would not have achieved category one. India has not been able to achieve that feat as big as they are. We have done that twice through NCAA. I’m not trying to flatter them, I don’t fear anybody, but they are doing great for the industry. I have told you the areas where I’m angry and bitter. NCAA is working and doing very well.

With your busy schedule, do you still have enough time to run your peace programme, Foundation for Ethnic Harmony in Nigeria (FEHN)?

Remember I told you earlier that if I had known that the kind of people you find in airline business are not the type you find in peace building, maybe, I may not have gone into it. My busy schedule does not affect the affairs of FEHN, because I have credible staff. We are like a family at FEHN. I don’t even look at their financial books, they know what to do. They are trustworthy and well trained outside our shores. I don’t do anything ad hoc or haphazard. If you want people to give you result, you train them well and motivate them well too. FEHN is me and I’m FEHN. I cannot throw FEHN away because of an airline. FEHN’s kind of work is like God’s calling, it is my own ministry, because when you transform an individual you feel fulfilled. Instead of quitting FEHN, I will close down Air Peace. If I’m to choose between FEHN and Air Peace, I will send Air Peace to the gallows and stick to FEHN. With FEHN, I’m directly touching lives of those who may be dangerous to the society. Moreover, Air Peace cannot give me the kind of money FEHN will give me. That is the truth, I train within and outside this country and paid heavily as a consultant. Whenever I advertise my programmes, people go to banks to pay to be able to attend my conflict management programmes that I handle with my American partners. Conflict management training is not for the dregs of the society or violent people only, no, it is for everybody. I still have contracts with Shell and others. Air Peace can’t do one third of what FEHN is doing for me. Is it not FEHN that produced the money I used in setting up Air Peace?

As a busy CEO, do you still practice law?

No, I don’t go the courts again, but I practised so well for 15 years. It was clashing with my peace building efforts so I had to give way. But I still counsel the young ones, my younger one is also a lawyer. I still proffer advice to people freely even though I no longer practice due to my busy schedules.

How do you also relax?

Well, the truth is that I only relax with my Ipad by working on it. So I don’t relax because when other people are sleeping, I’m awake and my wife is used to the way I work. I love work and go to bed most times, by 3.30am and could wake up before 5.30am, every day. I have done this since 1990. I have stayed till daybreak in this office working. I don’t sleep, I know it is not healthy and I don’t want anybody to emulate me. It makes me agitated sometimes and I have not gone for holidays too per se. I’m always working whenever I go on holidays with m family. I hardly shut down. It is not something good, but I can’t see myself going to bed before 3.am. In fact, I fight sleep because I hate sleep and don’t like sleeping. I used to enjoy watching football, but in the last one year I don’t think I have done that. My team is Tottenham, which I have been supporting since in the 80s as a teenager. I keep myself busy driving, I like driving myself. I like driving my convertibles, because I want to enjoy also and that is the only thing I enjoy. I like convertibles. When I drive my convertibles and play music I become happy. Again, how many hours do I even drive them, may be, 30 minutes to this place? Driving is the only way I recreate.

As a very fulfilled man, is there anything you still want from God?

Of course, everybody wants something from God. You want God to continue blessing you and to continue forgiving your sins. I’m a Catholic but have nothing against other faiths. A certain percentage of my gross earnings goes to evangelism and I have built churches and donated to different religions.

As a lover of peace and promoter of ethnic harmony, what is your advice to Nigerians as the general election approaches?

My advice is that Nigerians, mostly our politicians should remember that we have just one country. We should not allow our country to go the route of other African countries. Everybody must embrace peace. The election must be free and fair. Complaints should be properly addressed. People should not do anything that will be tantamount to rigging the elections. The contestants should be willing to accept victory and defeat respectively. If you know you have lost, willingly throw in the towel by congratulating the winner, this will help douse the tension. The situation where politicians promote violence is unsavoury. They should say no to hate speeches. The contestants should ensure their followers do not take to violence before, during and after the elections. Nigeria cannot develop in a state of rancour, hate and chaos. We can only develop in a state of peace. My advice to them is to play by the rules.

Do you have regrets in life?

Well, do I have any regret? Maybe, the only regret I have, that is not regret but losing my mum at a very young age still hurts. My mum died in 1991 at the age of 44. She died after four days of fever; I was young but had already graduated as a lawyer from UI.

The only regret I have is not representing this country at the Olympics. I was the sports man of the year in my school in 1984 at Government College Ughelli. As a secondary school student I was doing 10.4 seconds in 100 metres, without training. The guy who was coming a distant fifth Moses Oyiki, later represented Nigeria at the Olympics and people were asking where is Allen Onyema. I was not encouraged by my parents because I was meant to feel like an unserious person within the family, then everybody was shouting education and I happen to be the first son.

People in athletics and soccer didn’t go to school then, unlike now that you have graduates going into sports. My greatest regret is not having represented my nation at the Olympics. I would have loved to go to the Olympics and see myself crying with my flag being raised with a gold medal on my neck. And that was the only time I thought they would have played the national anthem for me. I’m not a governor, nor president. I love my country and that is my only regret.

Again, none of my kids are into sports. My daughter did athletics in secondary school, but she didn’t carry on. The boys are playing football, but not serious with it.

The only thing they are all doing is law. Ugochukwu is studying abroad for his A-levels.

As a rich Nigerian do you have the intention of going into politics someday?

It is not something I have given a thought. A lot of people try to push me. Even years back, some people told me to go into politics and contest for the governor of Anambra State, even the Senate. But I’m not interested. I believe that everybody must not be a president or governor to contribute to nation building. What I did for the Niger Delta is good example of how to contribute to the growth of your nation without vying for any political office. I’m not interested, but if I’m given an appointment, I can come and contribute. I believe I can contribute to the growth of my nation without going into the murky waters of partisan politics. A lot of bigwigs want me in politics because they believe I’m selfless, but I thanked them and also told them to allow me continue contributing from my own angle. You and I know that most good people don’t make it in politics. It is better you have your integrity intact and continue your good works from the outside according to the dictates of the Almighty.

The rumour is everywhere that Dame Patience Goodluck is the owner of Air Peace that you are just fronting for her. We would like you to clear the air on this rumour once and for all?

(Laughs and adjusts sitting position) I don’t even know Jonathan’s wife and have not even met her. If I see it in any newspaper that Patience Jonathan owns Air Peace, I will go to court. In fact, the newspaper will make my day. The peddlers of such rumours you know them. On one side, some politicians decided to be mischievous. On the other side, some rivals, decided to be mischievous too, believing that if they peddle such rumours a lot of people will not want to fly our planes. But that is a big lie, because people know the truth at all times. Which airline in Nigeria have rumour mongers not ascribed to one person or another? None. As the years went by, people have begun to see that those who came out ab initio as owners, are truly the owners of these airlines and not those people rumour mongers are ascribing ownership to. Every airline in this country was owned by people other than the real owners in the eyes of the public because of rumours like this, which is unfortunate. In Nigeria, is as if people have accepted poverty. They don’t believe that God gave them a lot of powers in their hands. It is just for you to look up to God almighty and find how you can harness it. If you continue denying God’s glory and favour on anybody, you are incurring the wrath of God.

And that is why such people will continuously be under because they don’t believe God. It is like you bringing money to help somebody go to school and people are all over the place saying that it wasn’t you that gave that money, but somebody else. How would you feel? They are annoying God with what they are saying. I have paid my dues in this country. I’m waiting for anybody to put it on print or come out and face me instead of speaking in secrecy like cowards. I don’t know Mrs. Jonathan and she does not own Air Peace. I don’t even want to be debunking things like this, because I have talked about it severally. It is not something I want to occupy my time with. I have told you how I came to float Air Peace. Banks that helped me are there. It is not something I want to discuss. Not only Mrs. Jonathan, they have ascribed the ownership of Air Peace to so many people, including the owner of Peace Mass Transit. About seven people have been named as the owners of Air Peace. All these are happening because I don’t like making noise, it is not needed. May be, if I were making noise before, I may not have reached this stage. Distractions will always be there. I don’t know anybody that will own an airline and allow another person to incorporate it with his name, names of his children and family. Who is that foolish patron that will allow you front for him like that? It is sheer stupidity on the part of those peddling such rumour. As long as they do not apologise to God, they will incur the wrath of God and will never know peace in their lives. They will never be able to achieve anything worth talking about in their lives, because they are not happy with another person’s success. One particular airline in this country gathered some journalists and told them to publish lies that Air Peace is owned by Mrs. Jonathan. These journalists started contacting me over the issue. These are rivals that are scared of me, but it does not bother me. I don’t want to lose focus on the real thing. My focus is on the real thing and not on side talks. Beer parlour talks do not perturb me. But I repeat, anybody who does not praise God for Air Peace but sees it as a front, will never, never know peace. If I’m fronting for anybody may I never know peace. If I’m fronting for anybody may God deny me anything good in my life. It is hurtful because they are not praising God and His good works. May I never get it right in anything I do if I’m fronting for anybody. And if not, those peddling this rumour will never see anything good in their lives.

What is your dream and vision for Air Peace as well as the legacy you want to leave behind?

Well, I put it up on my bb that Air Peace is the airline that would outlive this generation. Some airlines have been there since 1920s and still flying, this is also my dream for Air Peace. We will be there to continue providing jobs and peace to generation of Nigerians unborn. Air Peace is for peace and national cohesion and that is my conviction, wish and desire.

Once again, congratulations on your recent chieftaincy title in Mbosi, Ihiala LGA of Anambra State. How does that make you feel?

Well, it is something I had always resisted. I didn’t want to do anything with those chieftaincy issues, but the people felt I should be honoured and my dad also felt I should take it. So I had to respect the wishes of my father and that of the people of Ihiala LGA and accepted. So I feel good that my people have recognised the little good things that I’m doing in our communities and decided to honour me.

First published on Daylight in May, 2015.

Not only Mrs. Jonathan, they have ascribed the ownership of Air Peace to so many people, including the owner of Peace Mass Transit.

articles.title: How soldiers on reprisal invaded Imo community, burnt hotel, houses
articles.text:
Gunmen on Monday afternoon killed a military officer when they attacked some soldiers in Awo Mmamma in the Oru East Local Government Area of Imo State.

In reprisal, military men regrouped, invaded the town and allegedly burnt a hotel, cars, houses and shops.

The incident which reportedly happened at Ishieke junction has caused panic in the area.

Many indigenes of the community have fled their homes as soldiers took over the community.

A source said, “Some hoodlums attacked some soldiers at Ishieke junction in Awo Mmamma and killed one of them. They zoomed off towards Ihiala in Anambra state. Later, soldiers invaded the area and caused havoc in the area by setting a hotel, cars, houses and stalls on fire.

“As we speak, people are taking refuge in bushes. Military men are ravaging our community. It is on fire. There is serious arson here.”

The spokesperson for the State Police Command, Micheal Abattam, did not respond to a text message sent to him by our correspondent.

Also, the spokesperson for the 34 Artillery Brigade Command, Obinze, Owerri, Sunday Akuga, did not take several calls made to his mobile number. Punch

articles.title: Lai Mohammed lists 10 gaps in EndSARS panel report, insists no massacre
articles.text:
Minister of Information Lai Mohammed has thrown the report of the Lagos Judicial Panel into the dustbin, insisting there was no massacre at Lekki Toll Gate.

Mohammed said he was out of Nigeria when the report of the EndSARS judicial panel was submitted to the Lagos State Governor, Babajide Sanwo-Olu last week.

He has now digested the report and at a press conference in Abuja Tuesday, listed 10 gaping holes in the report:

Read him verbatim:

It’s no longer news that the Lagos State Judicial Panel of Inquiry that investigated cases of police brutality as well as the incident of Oct. 20th, 2020, at Lekki Toll Gate in Lagos has submitted its report. The submission happened while I was out of the country on national assignment. Unlike many commentators and analysts, we took our time to read and digest the report, and we are now well placed to respond.

Without mincing words, let me say that never in the history of any Judicial Panel in this country has its report been riddled with so many errors, inconsistencies, discrepancies, speculations, innuendoes, omissions and conclusions that are not supported by evidence. What is circulating in public space is simply a rehash of the unverified fake news that has been playing on social media since the incident of Oct.

20th 2020. It is simply incredible that a Judicial Panel set up to investigate an incident has submitted a report laden with allegations, the same allegations it was set up to investigate in the first instance. Instead of sitting for all of one year, the panel could have just compiled social media ‘tales by the moonlight’ on the incident and submitted, saving taxpayers’ funds and everyone’s time. That report is nothing but the triumph of fake news and the intimidation of a silent majority by a vociferous lynch mob.

We have read some critical analysis of the report by a courageous few. One commentator, a lawyer, said it raised more questions than answers. Another commentator, a journalist, called it a ‘disgraceful report by a disgraceful panel’, saying it reported allegations instead of investigating the allegations. Yet another wondered how a Judicial Panel could use the words ‘massacre in context’ and equate such to a massacre. All these and many more have raised valid questions on that report. We salute their courage and refusal to be cowed by the rampaging lynch mob that has been screaming blue murder since the report was released.

We do not intend to bore you by rehashing details of the discrepancies, innuendoes, inconsistencies and errors in that report. They are already in the public space. Let us, however, point out some key highlights of such discrepancies, errors, omissions, etc.

The report threw away the testimony of ballistic experts who testified before it. The experts said, inter alia, in their testimony:

”The Team finds that from the medical data examined, including the

timeline of arrival at medical facility and the nature of the injuries

sustained by the Victims, who were taken to the 5 medical facilities,

that no military grade live ammunition (high-velocity) was fired at

the protesters at Lekki Tollgate on 20th October 2020, within the

timeframe of reference (18.30- 20.34hrs). That the GSW (Gun Shot

Wounds) injuries (4 in number between 19:05 and 19:45 hrs), which were

examined by the Team, can be safely identified as being discharged by

either low velocity caliber and/or artisanal/12-gauge firearms

(artisanal firearms are locally-fabricated weapons). What is however

certain is that had the military personnel deliberately fired military

grade live ammunition directly at the protesters; there would have

been significantly more fatalities and catastrophic injuries

recorded. This was clearly not the case.’’

The same panel that said it deemed as credible the evidence of the Forensic Pathologist, Prof. John Obafunwa, that only three of the bodies on which post mortem were conducted were from Lekki and only one had gunshot injury went on to contradict itself by saying nine persons died of gunshot wounds at Lekki!

The man whose evidence (that he counted 11 bodies in a military van where he was left for dead before he escaped) was found to be crucial by the panel never testified in person. Rather, the video of his ‘testimony’ was played by someone else. It did not occur to the panel to query the veracity of the testimony of a man who said he was

shot and presumed dead but still had time to count dead bodies inside a supposedly dark van at night!

The panel said trucks with brushes underneath were brought to the Lekki Toll Gate in the morning of Oct. 21 2020 to clean up bloodstains and other evidence, but still found bullet casings at the same site when it visited on Oct. 30th 2020. It said soldiers picked up bullet casings from Lekki Toll Gate on the night of Oct. 20th 2020, yet claimed that policemen came to the same spot to pick the same bullet casings on Oct. 21st 2020!

The panel was silent on the family members of those reportedly killed, merely insinuating they were afraid to testify. Even goats have owners who will look for them if they do not return home, not to talk of human beings. Where are the family members

of those who were reportedly killed at Lekki Toll Gate? If the panel is recommending compensation for the families, what are their identities and addresses? Who will receive the compensations when no family members have shown up to date?

How did a man who reported seeing the lifeless body of his brother himself ended up being on the list of the panel’s deceased persons?

How can a Judicial Panel convince anyone that the names of some casualties of the Lekki Toll Gate incident listed as numbers 3 (Jide), 42 (Tola) and 43 (Wisdom) are not fictitious names.

Why did the Judicial Panel feel compelled to concoct a ”massacre in context” as a euphemism for ”massacre”? A massacre is a massacre. What is ”massacre in context?”



The report never mentioned cases of police personnel who were brutally murdered or the massive destruction of police stations, vehicles, e.t c during the Endsars protest. Does this mean that the panel didn’t consider policemen and women as human beings?

The report didn’t make any recommendation on the innocent people whose businesses were attacked and destroyed during the protest in Lagos. I think it was too busy looking for evidence to support its conclusion of ‘massacre in context’.



It is clear, from the ongoing, that the report of the panel in circulation cannot be relied upon because its authenticity is in doubt. Besides, the Lagos State Government, being the convening authority, has yet to release any official report to the public.

Neither has the panel done so. The cowardly leakage of an unsigned report to the public is not enough. Assuming the report in circulation bears any iota of genuineness, it is basic knowledge that the report of such a panel is of no force until the convening authority issues a White Paper and Gazette on it. It is therefore too premature for any

person or entity to seek to castigate the Federal Government and its agencies or officials based on such an unofficial and unvalidated report.

CNN AND OTHERS

The CNN has been celebrating the leaked report of the Lagos State Judicial Panel of Inquiry. In its rush to claim vindication, CNN apparently didn’t even read the report before rolling out the drums in celebration. By that action, CNN has celebrated prematurely and has now committed a double faux pas: First, by relying on unverified

social media stories and videos to carry out an investigation of the Oct. 20th 2020 incident at Lekki, where it did not have a correspondent on ground. CNN goofed in its report on the findings of the panel, which fell below the main standards of journalism. Secondly, CNN rushed to the air to celebrate an unsigned and unverified report that is riddled with inconsistencies, errors, discrepancies, innuendoes. That’s double faux pas by a news organization that is eager and willing to compromise

standards just to claim vindication.



Sadly, a section of the Nigerian media has also joined the lynch mob. Honestly, in an attempt to vilify government at all costs, they have done themselves a great disservice. How can any news organization worth its salt write an Editorial validating this kind of report? Are they not seeing what others, including journalists and lawyers, are seeing? In a shocking twist, a Nigerian newspaper chose to hail what it calls ‘’detailed investigative report’’ by CNN, even when the news channel did not even cover the incident of Oct. 20th 2020! It’s a classic case of cutting your nose to spite your face.

CONCLUSIONS

Gentlemen, there is absolutely nothing in the report that is circulating to make us change our stand that there was no massacre at Lekki on Oct. 20th 2020. For us to change our stand, a well-investigated report of the incident that meets all required

standards and will withstand every scrutiny must be produced and presented to the public. The report in circulation does not meet those requirements. We also appeal to the families of those allegedly killed in Lekki to speak out. It’s untenable to say that some families did not come out because they are afraid. Any parent who is afraid to testify about the death of his or her child is not worth to be called a parent.

We reject the notion that our soldiers and policemen massacred innocent Nigerians at Lekki on Oct. 20th 2020. That conclusion is not supported by the weight of available evidence. Indictment for murder is a very serious issue that cannot be done on the basis of allegations and corroborations, as the panel did. Such allegations must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt. The report in circulation is calculated to embarrass the Federal Government and its agencies without foolproof evidence. The Federal Government has never condoned the abuse of the rights of Nigerians by security agencies under any guise, hence it disbanded SARS and encouraged states to set up the panels to investigate reports of human rights abuses allegedly committed by the disbanded SARS personnel

The 37 policemen and six soldiers who died across the country during the Endsars protest are also Nigerians and should not be forgotten.

Those who have engaged in premature celebration of the report in circulation should now go back and read it thoroughly and tell Nigerians whether it can pass any serious scrutiny.

We are saddened that anyone died at all during the Endsars protest as the life of every Nigerian and indeed every human is sacrosanct. As we have disclosed many times, 57 civilians, 37 policemen and six soldiers were killed across the country during the protest, and we commiserate with their families.
articles.summary:
Minister of Information Lai Mohammed has thrown the report of the Lagos Judicial Panel into the dustbin, insisting there was no massacre at Lekki Toll Gate.
Mohammed said he was out of Nigeria when the report of the EndSARS judicial panel was submitted to the Lagos State Governor, Babajide Sanwo-Olu last week.
Yet another wondered how a Judicial Panel could use the words ‘massacre in context’ and equate such to a massacre.
Why did the Judicial Panel feel compelled to concoct a ”massacre in context” as a euphemism for ”massacre”?
CNN AND OTHERSThe CNN has been celebrating the leaked report of the Lagos State Judicial Panel of Inquiry.

articles.title: Lawan issues Appropriations C’ttee deadline to conclude budget defense
articles.text:
President of the Senate, Ahmad Lawan, has given the Committee on Appropriations till Wednesday this week to conclude budget defense by subcommittees of the upper chamber.

Lawan explained that the ultimatum became necessary in keeping with the December 14 timetable for the passage of the 2022 budget by the National Assembly.

He added that working to the contrary may mar the timely passage of the budget as planned.

The Senate President, nevertheless, assured Nigerians that the National Assembly would work assiduously in ensuring that it resolves any likely hitch that may interfere with the quick passage of the budget next month.

He commended ministries, departments and agencies of government for appearing before the committees of the chamber to defend their respective budget estimates.

Lawan said, “According to our timetable for the budget defense and subsequent processing by out committees or subcommittees of the Appropriations Committee, tomorrow will be the last day for the budget defense.

“Tomorrow will be the last day for the budget defense by subcommittees for appropriation before the committee on appropriations.

“It is gladdening that all our committees have finished their budget defense with ministries, departments and agencies as programmed by this Senate. But we have a little bit of a hitch, we are behind schedule with some of our committees.

“So, I’m sure that those committees that should have appeared before the committee on appropriation, but could not might have had some challenges with getting some details from the MDAs.

“Tomorrow, no matter what, we have to conclude with the budget defense by the subcommittees before the committee on appropriations, and it is very important.”

Explaining why work on the budget must be concluded in good time, Lawan said, “In fact, it is very, very essential that we keep to our timetable, otherwise, we may run into a very serious problem with our time for the budget to be considered and passed by the 14th of December.

“I’m sure that our committees will be able to appear before the committee on appropriations by tomorrow.

“[And] I will also add that the committee on appropriations should make itself available to our subcommittees for appropriation.

“We have up to the weekend to conclude on the work of defense by the subcommittees before the appropriations committee, so that the appropriations committee is able to also work to compile the document for us to work with, when we come to the next segment for the budget processing – that is the laying, consideration and passage of the budget proposal by the grace of God.

“I want to take this opportunity to thank all our committees for doing very well so far, and I’m sure that this little hitch is not something that we cannot deal with.

“On the whole, the program is going on, and I’m particularly glad that we have been able to finish the defense by the MDAs, and also commend the MDAs for coming forward to defend rather than leaving us to do what we think they want.”
articles.summary:
President of the Senate, Ahmad Lawan, has given the Committee on Appropriations till Wednesday this week to conclude budget defense by subcommittees of the upper chamber.
Lawan explained that the ultimatum became necessary in keeping with the December 14 timetable for the passage of the 2022 budget by the National Assembly.
Lawan said, “According to our timetable for the budget defense and subsequent processing by out committees or subcommittees of the Appropriations Committee, tomorrow will be the last day for the budget defense.
“Tomorrow will be the last day for the budget defense by subcommittees for appropriation before the committee on appropriations.
“It is gladdening that all our committees have finished their budget defense with ministries, departments and agencies as programmed by this Senate.

articles.title: BREAKING: Gunmen Raze Imo Police Station, Kill Cop
articles.text:
Gunmen have attacked and burnt a police Divisional headquarters in Arondizuogu in Ideato Local Government Area of Imo state.

The attack which happened around 2:00 am on Tuesday left one of the police officers on duty dead.

Sources in the community disclosed that the attack left the Divisional Police Officer of the Division with a broken head after he was attacked by the invaders.

Also, a Sienna vehicle attached to the division and DPO’s personal vehicles were vandalized by the gunmen.

“Gunmen have attacked the Arondizuogu Divisional Police Headquarters. They burnt and killed one of the police officers. The attacked at the odd hours and left the DPO with a broken head. They gave him matchet cuts and vandalized his Jeep and a police sienna vehicle belonging to the division,” a source who pleaded anonymity told Punch Newspapers.

The police spokesperson for the command, Micheal Abattam, confirmed the attack to Punch in a text message and added that the state Commissioner of Police, Rabiu Hussaini, had ordered an investigation into the attack.

The police spokesperson wrote, “Yes. The CP is on his way there.”

articles.title: APC Leader, Bola Tinubu’s 2023 Presidential Manifesto Leaks
articles.text:
While speculations about Asiwaju Bola Ahmed Tinubu’s interest in the 2023 presidential election have been rife for months, the leak of the former Lagos State governor’s manifesto has put to rest any doubts about whether the All Progressives Congress (APC) chieftain would run for the country’s top job.

According to Naija News, Tinubu got a leaked manifesto over the weekend, indicating that it is just a matter of time before he declares his candidacy for the presidency.

The manifesto, titled “Seven Point Agenda: The Rebirth Manifesto,” outlined Tinubu’s vision for Nigeria if he were elected president.

Education, technology, infrastructure, domestic enterprise, leadership, true federalism, and democratic process were among the seven essential issues included in the campaign master plan.

Leadership

Provide transformational leadership that has the ability to unify all of Nigeria and lead us to the attainment of shared goals and vision.

Technology

Leverage modern technology for digital transformation and economic growth.

Security

Create conditions that allow citizens move and transact freely across the Nation.

Infrastructure

Commence extensive infrastructural development by building basic foundational services (24 hrs access to electricity, roads, bridges e.t.c) that connect (power) people and businesses ultimately improving the quality of living.

Homegrown Businesses

Build platforms that enable and empower homegrown businesses to scale and compete favourably in the global market.

Education

Deploy initiatives targeted at promoting knowledge and equipping learners of all age groups with the skills and values needed to address modern-day challenges globally. Propagate and activate strategies that also promote a sense of pride and awakening amongst all Nigerian citizens to the extent that people feel extremely patriotic and ecstatic to be Nigerians.

True Federalism and Democratic Processes

Promote democracy, realize human potential and create conditions for prosperity and progress.

Sources disclosed to Naija News that Tinubu, a former Lagos State governor, would declare his presidential ambition officially.

“Our leader (Tinubu) would declare interest in the presidency very soon. We are confident he is the man to take Nigeria forward if you look at what he has been able to achieve both in government and privately,” the source said.

Bola Tinubu has remained silent about his interest in the role despite the rumors and speculations.

Several organizations, including the South West Agenda for Asiwaju (SWAGA), have instead taken it upon themselves to rally support for Tinubu’s candidacy.

Tinubu’s latest moves, which included a visit to Kano State earlier this year, have given his presidential ambitions even more legitimacy.

According to observers, the visit was designed at bolstering connections with the north ahead of the next election.

Orji Uzor Kalu, a former governor of Abia State, recently paid Tinubu a visit, sparking rumors about his bid to succeed Buhari.

Despite the allure of presidential authority and his influence in Nigeria’s political environment, particularly his role in President Muhammadu Buhari’s ascent in 2015, many experts say the former Action Congress leader should be a kingmaker rather than a king.

The manifesto, titled “Seven Point Agenda: The Rebirth Manifesto,” outlined Tinubu’s vision for Nigeria if he were elected president.

Tinubu’s latest moves, which included a visit to Kano State earlier this year, have given his presidential ambitions even more legitimacy.

articles.title: Imo Residents Flee Homes As Gunmen Kill Soldiers
articles.text:
Hundreds of residents in Awo-Mmamma community, Oru East Local Government Area, Imo State, who evacuated their houses after gunmen allegedly killed a military man on Monday afternoon expressed disappointment at having to spend the night in the bush.

On Monday, sources within the Awo-Mmamma village told a DAILY POST correspondent that there had been a large flight of people, particularly youngsters, from the community due to dread of the unknown.

He described the horrific situation as follows: “Some hoodlums attacked some soldiers at Ishieke junction in Awo Mmamma and killed one of them, then zoomed off towards Ihiala in Anambra State, where the soldiers invaded and caused havoc by setting a filling station, cars, houses, hotel, and stores on fire in retaliation.”

According to a community leader who requested anonymity, the horrible occurrence at Ishieke intersection resulted in the destruction of property worth millions of Naira.

He said, “as I speak to you now, many more houses may be burnt tonight. We’re now at the mercy of angry soldiers.

“Hundreds of our people may pass this night in the bush. Our people have escaped from their land while those still remaining now live in fear,” he said

When contacted, the Police spokesperson, Micheal Abattam directed our correspondent to reach out to the Army.

The Army Spokesman, when contacted said he will get back to us, but as at the time of filing the report, he was yet to get back.
